â
The basic salaries at Google were, before the IPO, considered to be quite low compared to industry standards. For instance, some [[system administrator]]s earned no more than $33,000–37,000: is considered to be low by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] standard levels, but excellent stock performance has left these early employees well compensated. In recent times, Google has implemented other incentives such as the [http://blog.monkeymethods.org/2005/02/google-founders-awards-is-good-idea-tm.html Founder's award], as well as offering higher salaries to new employees.
+
Prior to the IPO offering, typical salaries at Google were considered within the industry to be quite low. For instance, some [[system administrator]]s earned no more than $33,000– while $37,000 at that time was considered to be low by [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] market levels. Nevertheless, Google's excellent stock performance following the IPO has enabled these early employees to be well compensated by participation in the corporation's remarkable equity growth. In 2005 Google has implemented other emplyee incentives such as the [http://blog.monkeymethods.org/2005/02/google-founders-awards-is-good-idea-tm.html Founder's award], as well as offering higher salaries to new employees.
â
Beyond monetary compensation, Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity , stellar prospects (relative to most Bay Area companies), and strong brand recognition continue to attract far more applicants than there are positions available (it is estimated that less than one job offer is made per thousand resumes submitted). As a result, Google reportedly had to hire one in-house legal recruiter just to assit the legal department sort through resumes from job seeking [[attorney]]s.
+
Beyond monetary compensation, Google's workplace amenities, culture, global popularity , stellar prospects (relative to most Bay Area companies), and strong brand recognition continue to attract far more applicants than there are positions available. (It is estimated that less than one job offer is made per thousand resumes submitted). Google reportedly employs one in-house legal recruiter just to assist the legal department in evaluating the high volume of resumes from employment seeking [[attorney]]s.
